conclusion: A semi-circular wire frame with a radius of \\( r \\) is formed by connecting wires of the same material and thickness.
The wire frame is fixed in a uniform magnetic field, and the plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic induction intensity.
Points \\( M \\) and \\( N \\) are connected to the two terminals of a direct current constant voltage power supply.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the straight part of the wire frame is \\( F \\).
The straight part of the wire frame has a length of \\( 2r \\).
The current \\( I \\) can be found using the relation \\( F = B I (2r) \\).
Solving for \\( I \\), we get \\( I = \frac{F}{2rB} \\).
The curved part of the wire frame is a semi-circle with a radius \\( r \\).
The length of the curved part is \\( \pi r \\).
The force on a segment of the curved part is \\( dF = B I dL \\).
Integrating over the semi-circle, the total force on the curved part is \\( F_{\text{curved}} = B I (\pi r) \\).
Using \\( I = \frac{F}{2rB} \\), we substitute into the expression for \\( F_{\text{curved}} \\): \\( F_{\text{curved}} = \frac{F \pi r}{2r} = \frac{F \pi}{2} \\).
The total force on the wire frame is the sum of the forces on the straight and curved parts: \\( F_{\text{total}} = F + \frac{F \pi}{2} \\).
Therefore, the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is \\( F \left( 1 + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \\).
